Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Efficient Ranking and Aggregate Query Processing for Probabilistic Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
When dealing with massive quantities of data, ranking and aggregate
queries are powerful techniques for focusing attention on the most
important answers. Many applications that produce such massive
quantities of data inherently introduce uncertainty in the same time,
for example, probabilistic match in data integration, imprecise
measurements from sensors, fuzzy duplicates in data cleaning,
inconsistency in scientific data. Hence, the importance of these
queries is even greater in probabilistic data, where a relation can
encode exponentially many possible worlds. Uncertainty opens the gate
to many possible definitions for ranking and aggregate queries. This
project systematically examines the underlying properties associated
with the rich semantics of ranking and aggregate queries for large
amounts of probabilistic data. More importantly, this project
investigates the issue of how to design novel and scalable algorithms
for processing these queries efficiently in various settings, such as
the offline, centralized environment, distributed systems and the
streaming model.

With the emergence of probabilistic data in many important application
domains, the demand for understanding and processing the ranking and
aggregate queries efficiently from the scientific community and beyond
(e.g., government and military agencies) is expected to intensify in
the coming years. The results of this project lay down a firm
foundation for this important problem.

For further information, such as publications, data sets and source code,
please see the project website at http://www.cs.fsu.edu/~lifeifei/rankaggprob

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explores two classes of important query operators for large databases and data sets that contain uncertainty. Examples of uncertainty include but not limited to measurement and readings data, results of data integration and data cleaning, ambiguity from text and unstructured data. With the fast increase in the amount of data different applications have to deal with, amount of uncertainty is only expected to grow.

Uncertainty introduces notable challenges for query processing. Each probabilistic data set represent potentially exponential number of possible instances of deterministic databases. Thus, using the popular possible worlds semantics, query processing in probabilistic databases can be costly. Even simple reporting queries can become very expensive, since many records will have some probability to be included in the results. Thus, this project concentrates on ranking and aggregation operators, that help users focus their attention on most important records or succinct representation of the underlying data sets. Novel query processing techniques have been developed and they can handle a wide range of ranking and aggregation operations in large probabilistic data. In addition, a robust framework to analyze query semantics for extending various query definitions to uncertain data is also made available. 

Techniques developed under this project have been thoroughly tested using a number of different data sets and application scenarios. The results also extend to uncertainty in unstructured data, such as text, string, and keyword data sets.

The results in the project have been disseminated to the science disciplines and community at large through publications, open source libraries, presentations, demos, and research open house. A number of undergraduate and graduate students were supported by this project and participated in various research activities related to the project. Research results in this project have also been integrated into course development, education and outreach activities. All findings, publications, source code, data sets, and posters produced in this project are available at the project website. 

The outcomes of this project have important applications in various domains that have to work with uncertainty in the data, for example, in various scientific projects, and data integration and data cleaning scenarios. As a result, publications produced in this project have generated high citations, indicating active follow-up works based on the results and findings from this project.


Last Modified: 12/03/2013
Modified by: Feifei Li
